title: What's going on with Tua Tagovailoa? NFL legend weighs in | Marca
text:
Tua Tagovailoa , quarterback of the Miami Dolphins , is facing one of the most difficult stretches of his career.
As the team sits at 1-6, scrutiny over his performance and the offense's lack of rhythm has intensified. Hall of Fame quarterback Kurt Warner believes the root of the problem comes down to one factor: confidence.
Miami Dolphins fans are done with Tua Tagovailoa and they demand a new quarterback Appearing on the Rich Eisen Show , Warner said the Dolphins appeared to be second-guessing themselves, starting with their quarterback.
"They've lost confidence," Warner said. "And it's not that they don't have talent. It's that they're hesitant."
The reality is stark: Tagovailoa has one of the most talented supporting casts in the league, but the results have not reflected that potential.
Tua Tagovailoa's confidence is wavering The Dolphins entered the season with big expectations. Tagovailoa signed a major contract extension and returned with elite playmakers around him.
But recent performances have exposed hesitation in his reads and inconsistencies in his execution. Warner identified the issue clearly: "When your quarterback starts hesitating, defenders know it. They attack the pace."
Offseason injuries and concussion history have added more pressure. Tagovailoa was once praised for his quick release and decision-making, but defenses are now keying in on him earlier in plays, forcing him to extend and improvise - something he's struggled with in recent weeks.
His accuracy remains elite when he releases the ball quickly, but broken plays have highlighted weaknesses in his pocket awareness and improvisation.
As one former coach told Sports Illustrated , his "hero mode" can no longer cover deeper structural problems in the offense.
The problems aren't only about Tagovailoa . Head coach Mike McDaniel 's timing-based system depends heavily on his quarterback being in rhythm.
When hesitation creeps in, the entire offense stalls. Warner said: "The shot-clock is part of your training - the decision-making must be automatic."
The Dolphins still have stars like Tyreek Hill and Jaylen Waddle , and a strong backfield that can support an explosive attack. But short drives and missed red zone chances have become too common.
"When you're fighting from behind, everything gets harder," Warner added.
Even with elite talent, the offense can't function if its leader lacks conviction. Opposing defenses have taken advantage, pressing receivers and forcing Tagovailoa to make tougher reads late in the play clock.
Rebuilding confidence is the key For Tagovailoa , the path forward is clear but difficult. He needs to trust his reads again, play fast, and regain the confidence that once defined his style.
Warner believes it's about simplifying and rebuilding step by step: "When you return to playing instinctively, the stats will follow."
For the Miami Dolphins as a whole, the solution isn't just on the quarterback. The coaching staff needs to adjust protection schemes, reintroduce tempo, and emphasize short-decision plays to help Tagovailoa find his rhythm again.
At 1-6, the pressure is mounting. Whether Tua Tagovailoa can regain form - and whether Mike McDaniel can stabilize the system - may define the remainder of the Dolphins season.
